reviewText: This "series" is really just a collection of History Channel series episodes bundled together to create the impression that it is a comprehensive history series covering the empires of the ancient world. The set includes individual episodes come from HC's "Engineering An Empire"(e.g., Greece, Age of Alexander, The Aztecs, etc.), HC's "Rome: Rise and Fall of an Empire", "Ancients Behaving Badly", and "Barbarians". If you are expecting a presentation of even a good historical survey of each of the major empires of the world, you will be disappointed. If only the History Channel would actually produce in depth history series', but alas, we are stuck with "Ice Road Truckers" and other such nonsense.

reviewText: I think Alexander M. Walker did a pretty good review of the basicmegaset, so I won't restate his points.Currently at under a dollar per episode/program for $29.95 I think itwould be very hard to beat the bargain this set is - especially consideringhow expensive the individual sets and bonus programs were originally.They vary considerably in quality, and I personally wouldn't buy a couple of theseries singley, but the best ones are worth more individually than thetotal cost of the Megaset alone.
summary: The Best Value I've Ever Seen for History Channel Series

reviewText: For History nuts like me this is a great colection.  Only problem is that I had bought some earlier colections and found them to be compleate in this searies so check the wording closely to see what you already have so you don't end up with doubles.  But a great colection of leaders how empires were built and so much more  worth every penny.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First I want to say that I agree with the other reviewers in part that this is DVD collection of other History Channel series episodes all bundled together. However, for those who are not a big fan of the History Channel this is a good deal both in the form of price and amount of educational information contained within this collection. You are getting 14 disks with over 32 hours of documentary material at a cost of about $2.50 per disk, tough to beat that price. I had already purchased some of the individual series from the History Channel so I will probably give them away to those who can use them as an educational tool in a teaching environment. Overall I still recommend this set collection for purchase.
summary: A collection of other history channel DVD's

reviewText: This is an extremely well made series. Not too detailed but still power packed with very interesting details, enough to make you a bit smarter than you were before having watched the series. At these low prices, I say buy it! Its a great collectors item.
summary: A must have for all HIstory buffs
